texts.shortText: Laterally flattened and shrimp-like, with distinctive gaudy colour pattern. Body vertically banded in purple and white, eyes white with black spots, bases of antennae and distal parts of legs orange-red. Second pair of nippers with enlarged hand, palm of hand oblique, finely serrated and with 2 sharp triangular teeth, one near base of finger and one at junction with hind margin. Abdominal segment 4 with a single dorsal tooth and segment 5 with a pair of small teeth. Third uropods elongate and with one very short, oval branch and one much longer one.

Global: Endemic to South Africa.

Local/Regional: Saldanha Bay to Plettenberg Bay.
Poorly known, but the specimen depicted here was found in the shells of hermit crabs and may be a commensal in that habitat.
Unknown, probably herbivorous and/or detritus feeder, perhaps even feeding on faeces of hermit crabs, but this needs confirmation.

As in all amphipods males copulate with females and inseminate the eggs when they are released into the marsupium, which is situated between the legs of the female. There they develop into fully-formed juveniles before being released.

There are about a dozen regional species in the family Melitidae, these being characterized by the unusual form of the third uropod (one long branch and the other very short). Each species has teeth on the dorsal margin of some abdominal segments and they can be identified based on which segments bear teeth and numbers of teeth on each segment. This is the only regional species with one tooth on segment 4 and 2 teeth on segment 5. The colour pattern of live animals is also a useful identification feature and the bright colours of this species are diagnostic.
